greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: Binomial(2n, n) - 2 mod n^2.
comment: When e=2, the numbers binomial(2n, n)-2 mod n^e are 0 whenever n is a prime (see A246130 for introductory comments). This follows from Wolstenholme's theorem or, in a simpler way, from the identity binomial(2n, n)-2 = sum_{k=1..(n-1)} binomial(n,k)^2, in which every RHS term is divisible by n^2 whenever n is a prime. No composite number n for which a(n)=0 was found up to n=431500; nevertheless, the existence of such a composite is likely (personal opinion, based on the combinatorial nature of the problem).
link: Stanislav Sykora, Table of n, a(n) for n = 1..10000
results.author: _Stanislav Sykora_, Aug 16 2014
